Scaling Up Rural Sanitation
Factors Associated with Achieving and Sustaining Open Defecation Free Communities: Learning from East Java September 2011
KEY FINDINGS INTRODUCTION What does it take to bring about sustainable sanitation behavior â€¢ QUICKLY Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities rep- change, cost-effectively, and at scale? The search for answers has resent the most efficient model for scaling up sustainably. intensified in the rural sanitation sector in Indonesia, where access â€¢ ODF outcomes that materialize late, after many months of to improved sanitation has grown much too slowly from 22 per- cent in 1990 to just 36 percent in 2008,1 and the Millennium Devel- triggering, should be subject to intensive verification and opment Goal target for rural sanitation seems well beyond reach. periodic rechecks. Meanwhile economic losses from poor sanitation and hygiene are â€¢ Sanitation behavior change is difficult to ignite in river- costing Indonesia US$6.3 billion or 2.3 percent of its GDP per year.2 bank and waterfront communities and special strategies
The Water and Sanitation Programâ€™s (WSP) Global Scaling Up Rural are needed. Sanitation Project, a learning-by-doing initiative implemented in partner- â€¢ Poor quality Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) trig- ship with local and national governments in Indonesia, India, and Tan- gering is invariably associated with lack of ODF achieve- zania,3 sought answers by working at scale from the beginning and by ment, but good quality CLTS triggering alone does not testing a combination of two relatively new and promising approaches: Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) and sanitation marketing. guarantee ODF outcomes. â€¢ Provided CLTS triggering is of sufficient quality, ODF The subsidy-free CLTS4 approach is one that Indonesia field-trialed achievement and sustainability are hastened by: in 2005 with such positive results that by mid-2006, the Ministry of a) communityâ€™s social capital and the involvement of Health had changed ongoing national water and sanitation project strategies mid-stream, making CLTS the principal vehicle for scal- leadership in the change process, b) local availability ing up rural sanitation in Indonesia. Simultaneously, in Bangladesh, and affordability of latrine attributes desired by poor and Vietnam and some African countries, subsidy-free, market-based non-poor consumers, c) absence of externally provided sanitation programs were showing encouraging results in scaling up subsidies to a few households, and d) post-triggering access to sanitation in poor rural populations. In 2010, WSP conducted action research in East Java communities that had received CLTS triggering through the â€¢ Eighty focus group discussions (FGDs) with community-based project, to better understand the triggering processes and their conse- men and womenâ€™s groups, including community sanitation quences from the perspective of the people who had experienced them. committee members. Exploration included community perceptions of the triggering process; â€¢ Forty FGDs with open defecator and sharer household members. results of post-triggering monitoring and follow up; community views on what helped or hindered collective behavior change; what sanitation im- â€¢ Participatory analysis tools including timelines, welfare classifi- provements the poor and non-poor have invested in since triggering and cation, transect walk, and diagramming for fecal contamination why; motivations underlying current open defecation and sharing prac- routes. tices; abilities, opportunities and motivations of open defecators and â€¢ Observation of 574 latrines in poor, rich and in-between sharers to change sanitation behavior; school sanitation and hygiene households in 80 communities and interviews with latrine facilities in the communities; current institutional roles and capacity to owners. support rural sanitation development; and implications regarding insti- â€¢ Demonstration of the Informed Choice Catalogue of improved tutional capacity and incentives needed to support scaling up in light of sanitation facilities with open defecators and sharers in 40 NOT the study results. This Research Brief is based on a full report (in press). ODF communities. â€¢ Environmental observation with checklists. RESEARCH GOALS AND METHODOLOGY â€¢ Checking of community maps/records of monitoring sanitation The study goals were, first, to identify the factors that influence access and ownership of improved/unimproved sanitation in 80 the achievement and sustainability of collective behavior change communities. by communities to become ODF; and second, to understand what these findings might imply for improving program implementation effectiveness at scale. All of the project districts were approached KEY FINDINGS with the opportunity to participate, with 20 out of the 29 districts electing to participate (see Illustration 1). 1. QUICKLY ODF communities represent the most efficient model for scaling up sustainably. Eighty communities were selected from twenty districts using Communities that achieved ODF status within two months of trig- randomization from the universe of all triggered communities gering achieved markedly faster and higher access gains and re- grouped in four categories. WSPâ€™s field team used qualitative and mained ODF more often than communities that took many months participatory research methods6 to consult community members. to achieve ODF status (see Tables 1 and 2). INSIGHTS FOR PROGRAMMING TO SCALE For cost-efficient scaling up, districts need to plan rural sanita- UP ACHIEVEMENT OF â€œSUSTAINABLY ODFâ€? tion interventions by zoning, clustering and phasing communi- COMMUNITIES ties in response to specific conditions The study found evidence Indonesiaâ€™s continuing challenge is a persistently large rural sani- that CLTS triggering, follow up support, and monitoring strategies tation access gap. The WHO-UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programâ€™s need to be adjusted to both specific locations and conditions that af- 2010 Update states that over 58 million people currently practice fect open defecation practices and to the factors that motivate people open defecation,9 of which nearly 40 million are in rural areas. Another to continue such practices, such as: riverbank and beach communi- 51 million people share othersâ€™ latrines or use unimproved facilities, ties; swamp regions with high water tables, little dry land and transpor- of which 31 million live in rural areas. There is as yet no national rural tation problems; or water scarce regions. Using these criteria to plan sanitation program as seen in some South Asian countries.10 Among interventions by segmenting, zoning, and phasing sub-districts or clus- all stakeholders there is both concern about progress not being on ters of villages, would make for more cost-efficient logistics for demand track to achieve the MDG target, and keen interest in learning about creation, follow up, monitoring, and supply improvement facilitation. what will accelerate progress towards ODF communities at scaleâ€” which translates into rapid gains in access to sanitation. doc.repnme: Factors associated with achieving and sustaining open defecation free communities : learning from east java
doc.abstracts: The study goals were, first, to identify the factors that influence the achievement and sustainability of collective behavior change by communities to become Open Defecation Free (ODF); and second, to understand what these findings might imply for improving program implementation effectiveness at scale. All of the project districts were approached with the opportunity to participate, with 20 out of the 29 districts electing to participate. At project inception, East Java was home to 20 percent of the countries poor and had a total population of 37.4 million (exceeding the population of mid-size country such as Poland or Algeria), of whom 32.35 million lived in rural areas. Water and Sanitation Program (WSP) and all stakeholders agreed to study this issue through action research to bring the voices and perspectives of project communities into the search for answers.
